info.game_comments:
Jason McCune game 1.

(Sofia: Today on Jeopardy!: costumes from the big and small screen.  Test yourself--next.)

(1, 1).clue: Leodegrance, King of Cameliard, had Arthur as a son-in-law after this daughter's marriage

(2, 1).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew shows off an ancient costume.)  On "Hercules" or "Xena", a member of this warrior race wore the costume I'm wearing

(3, 1).clue: This long defensive barrier was designated a World Heritage site in 1987

(5, 1).clue: Before "Titanic", Kate Winslet was Marianne in the film of this "sense"-itive Austen novel

(6, 1).clue: The name of this burrowing mammal comes from a Spanish word for someone "armed" or "armored"

(1, 2).clue: Merlin didn't design this or buy it at Ikea--he copied it from Joseph of Arimathea

(2, 2).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew shows off a feline costume.)  It's the band led on-screen in 2001 by Rachel Leigh Cook in this outfit

(3, 2).clue: Once a spokesman for General Electric, Ronald Reagan earned this nickname as President

(5, 2).clue: Title characters are seen here in a '90s version of this work

(6, 2).clue: Reniform means shaped like this bodily organ; you may have a reniform pool

(1, 3).clue: This witch's name means she's a "fairy"

(2, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew shows off a black Spanish wig.)  In this 1998 film, Antonio Banderas cut Catherine Zeta-Jones out of the outfit I'm wearing

(3, 3).clue: It began in the house of the king's baker in Pudding Lane on September 2, 1666

(5, 3).clue: Clara Blandick played Auntie Em in "The Wizard of Oz" & Aunt Polly in a film based on this novel

(6, 3).clue: If you know this "bovine" term for a circular window, you're right on target

(1, 4).clue: We learned more about this nephew of Arthur in the 14th century tale titled him "and the Green Knight"

(2, 4).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew shows off a band camp T-shirt.)  One time at band camp, this actress wore the outfit I have on

(3, 4).clue: In 1954 Khufu's (or Choeps') funeral ship was discovered near this landmark, his tomb

(5, 4).clue: The film seen here is an adaptation of this classic American novel

(6, 4).clue: It's a synonym for "ashen" or a term for a region within an imposed boundary; don't go "beyond" it

(1, 5).clue: Some accounts say Arthur still lives on this mythic island

(2, 5).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew shows off a racing outfit.) The outfit I'm wearing acted as a disguise for Cameron Diaz in this 2000 film

(3, 5).clue: The Flinders' passage through this was named for the British explorer who ran aground on it in 1803

(5, 5).clue: Burgess Meredith was nominated for an Oscar for the Hollywood version of this Nathanael West Hollywood novel

(6, 5).clue: This French term for a pseudonym literally means "name of war"

(1, 1).clue: Arthur Vandenberg helped found this in 1945; Arthur Goldberg was a representative to it in the '60s

(2, 1).clue: This choreographer was the niece of the producer-director of "The Ten Commandments"

(4, 1).clue: In 2000 this "Three's Company" star seen here made an acclaimed Broadway debut in "The Dinner Party"

(5, 1).clue: On March 1, 1836 this mission got 32 reinforcements; on March 6 Mexican troops broke through the walls

(1, 2).clue: The record shows this Irish brewer came up with his Extra Stout Porter in the late 1700's

(2, 2).clue: Born in Russia, he became an Austrian citizen in 1982 & artistic director of the Paris Opera Ballet in 1983

(3, 2).clue: Full of exaggerated literary devices, like some prose

(4, 2).clue: In May 2001 Eric McCormack of "Will & Grace" willed himself to play professor Harold Hill in this musical revival

(5, 2).clue: Ali Razmara, this country's premier, was killed by a religious fanatic at a Teheran mosque March 7, 1951

(6, 2).clue: Where the Green Bay Packers play their home games

(1, 3).clue: He retired from tennis in 1980 & became a social activist for AIDS research

(2, 3).clue: In 1905 Michel Fokine created a 3-minute dance, "The Dying" this, that became closely associated with Anna Pavlova

(4, 3).clue: You could say that playing Murray in the 2001 revival of "A Thousand Clowns" was this actor's "Magnum" opus

(5, 3).clue: On March 8, 1862 this Confederate ironclad sank the Union's Cumberland

(1, 4).clue: Sir Arthur Evans dubbed the civilization he dug up on this island Minoan

(2, 4).clue: Part Native American, her 1997 autobiography was subtitled "America's Prima Ballerina"

(4, 4).clue: Once a Duke of Hazzard on TV, Tom Wopat is heard here on the 1999 cast album of this Broadway revival:"Anything you can be, I can be greater /Sooner or later, I'm greater than you..."

(5, 4).clue: The perfume of victory was sweet as allied troops captured this German city March 6, 1945

(6, 4).clue: A sparkling red wine of Italy

(1, 5).clue: It shouldn't take you "a thousand days" to come up with this shared name of father & son U.S. historians

(4, 5).clue: This star of TV's "Alice" earned critical raves for the hit comedy "The Tale of the Allergist's Wife"

(5, 5).clue: On March 3, 1815 the U.S. declared war on Algiers as part of these wars

(6, 5).clue: On the big screen he was "The Highlander", & also Tarzan

(0, 0).clue: This original cabinet post created in 1789 didn't get an accompanying department until 1870
